Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I glanced at the notice pinned to the site office door: “Optional Safety Training—Next Friday, 1:00 PM.” The foreman had already mentioned how important it was for everyone to attend, even if it wasn’t mandatory. “Shows you’re committed to the team,” he’d said, and I knew he’d be watching who showed up. But as I folded the paper into my pocket, my phone buzzed with a message from the mosque committee: “Looking forward to your sermon on ‘Patience in Hardship’ this Friday. The community is excited.” I was the only imam scheduled, and the topic had been announced for weeks. People would be coming with expectations, some even traveling from neighboring towns. My mind spun with the weight of both roles—my coworkers counting on me to be present, my congregation relying on my words. I felt the pressure building in my chest, torn between the loyalty to my team and the responsibility to my faith community, knowing that whatever I chose, someone would be disappointed.
